This movie is nothing short of an epic existential poem, beginning with a tragi-hopeful Hedwigian mythology of separation and return and culminating by debunking the very myth it sets up. Hedwig exits, a naked boy, the essentially solitary human being. The film is also a meditation on Rock'n'Roll's primarily unacknowledged debt to transsexual theory. It's a demanding work. Repeated watchings yield and yield. John Cameron Mitchell's performance is exquisite, and his writing--as well as Trax's--commanding.

absolutely hysterical! thanks for another "psycho beach party" experience. so much fun to sing along with too. we walked out of the theatre humming "i put on my make up. turn on the 8 track. take the wig down from the shelf" john, you are a genius for the new millenium.

A friend recommended this movie to me, and although I missed it in the theaters, I rented it as soon as it came out on video. I wish I HAD seen it in a theater, if for no other reason than to make Mitchell and Trask a small bit of money for what I found to be a truly amazing film. I hope they collaborate again.They've created a unique and engaging character in Hedwig, and one of the best soundtracks I've ever listened to. It's better than most "classic" rock operas - an inspiring mix of music and storytelling with hanting melodies and prophetic vocal lines. I found the melodies and lyrics swimming through my head for days after I saw the movie. Simply wonderful. I'm still haunted by the thought the we are all halves of beings who originally had two faces, two sets of arms, and two sets of legs.

Let down by mediocre film adaptations of Theater Musicals? Well, then Hedwig will surely change your mind about the genre. From the costumes and makeup to it's overly-dramatized portrayal of dreams gone bad, this film delivers entertainment at it's best. A stylish production entrenched in Glam Rock roots, this film obviously pays tribute and homage to David Bowie, and all gender-bending pioneers so closely linked to early punk and rock. The cinematographic artwork, animation, and direction flawlessly accentuate Hedwig's wit, music and melodrama.Cameron's performance is stellar and I must admit that they make him look quite attractive as a woman. This is not your "run of the mill" drag queen flick: Priscilla, Queen of the Desert...move over!

Every time I watch this movie (and I have watched it several times) I catch something that I missed. It is full of clever lines, irony, and humour, some of it dark, some of it just plain fun (their agent is Phyllis Stein). I loved the music, my favourite is  "Wig in a Box'. The performances were excellent, the costumes were outrageous  I could go on and on. This is not a macho car chase movie, not a chick flick  it is an acquired taste, shall we say. If you like `Priscilla Queen of the Desert', give it a try.

I'm straight. I despise musicals. I'm not homophobic, but am generally somewhat averse to drag queens. That said, this transgender musical is one of the best movies I have ever seen.The music is great. The comedy is hilarious. The drama is gripping. But what makes this movie truly good, is Hedwig.The flawed and complex character of Hedwig is played with such honest depth, you cannot help but empathize with her. It is amazing that such an over the top, glam-rocker, transgender/drag queen character can be anything more than a shallow stereotype in the movie industry. She is not only anti-stereotypical, but is one of the most profoundly genuine characters ever put to celluloid. John Cameron Mitchell perfectly executed the trifecta of writing, directing, acting, and singing (wait, that's a quadfecta???).I can't recommend this film enough.

reviews.review_title: Just see it, you KNOW you want to.
reviews.content: This movie is amazing. If for nothing else you need to see it for the music. It had everything you could ever want: good music, acting, and story(not common in musicals might I add). Sure, the story is kind of a cheezy idea, but it is done so well and comes off so well you'll love it. The end is so spectacular, you'll watch it over and over again just to see that one scene. I hope this replaces Rocky Horror as the most accepted glam rock transvestite movie. Just see it, now. Not even kidding, just do it.

I caught this film on Satellite and almost skipped it until I saw Stephen Trask was in it, albeit pretty hard to find at first.  Stephen is responsible for many Glam rockers and their movements.  Anyway, a poetic journey of, well, a transsexual's musical career or lack there of.  Totally brilliant acting by all cast members and the characters they have created. The music score is thanks to the brilliant Stephen Trask, and punches glam poetic rock to the maximum, a definite CD must for any fan.  Not much can be said without giving the best bits away in this film, only that its one the heterosexual males may skip over, or only see alone or with girlfriend but if you do happen to catch yourself watching it, im sure Hedwig will tantalite your senses, laughter and perhaps your own inch.  A Must See! 10/10.

reviews.review_title: I really really really like this movie a lot
reviews.content: I am the type of person to be very skeptical over movies. A friend of mine handed me Hedwig and the Angry Inch before I could say anything.I wasn't so sure about it. But I ended up watching it 3 times, so it's pretty good and I really enjoyed it.

This is probably one of the most remarkable films of 2001. First seeing it on stage, when I heard it was a film I went insane. The casting couldn't be better, the music is just fantastic, and John Cameron Mitchell is the prettiest transvestite in that Farrah Fawcett wig.

reviews.review_title: Great movie, although Hedwig's actions may bother some
reviews.content: The first time I watched this movie I gave it a three out of five stars. The reason for this was because of Hedwig's actions. Hedwig openly admits to saying he did some "jobs some called blow". This, to me, indicates that he was giving guys "blowjos" and not letting them know he was really a man. That grosses me out, as I'm sure it would a lot of viewers. I have nothing against transsexuals or hermaphrodites or whatever, but to do that to someone and have them not know what you really are is deceptive and personally, makes me want to punch them in the friggin' face, if not something more violent.The other unacceptable action of Hedwig's was "jerking off" Tommy Gnosis when he didn't know Hedwig's true nature, either. Hedwig angers me for that reason alone, that he doesn't seem to care about other people, but at the same time, you have to sympathize with him.The only thing that prevents me from giving this movie a ten is Hedwig's unforgivable actions and unforgivable taste in music. (Velvet Underground... No. DON'T take a walk on the wild side, let the person decide for themselves instead of you're brainwashing, Lou Reed... and Heroin sucks.) Also, the Rolling Stones are horrible. They're like dinosaurs. The only good artist Hedwig listens to is David Bowie. My personal opinion here, of course.My only point here is that Hedwig may anger some, so if you are easily angered by the selfish actions of others, so will you be at this movie at first glance. I recommend going out and watching "Rocky Horror Picture Show" first to soften the blow, so to speak.

reviews.review_title: Impressive adaptation from stage to screen
reviews.content: The stage version was more rock 'n' roll but the film carries with it a heavier emotional impact. Definitely a new twist on the meaning of freedom. If you are looking at purchasing the soundtrack be sure to purchase the original cast recording not the orignal motion picture soundtrack.

I guess I stray from the ranks of the obsessed here and tell it how I saw it...Hedwig was a good movie and I was entertained, but I cannot agree that the movie was life-changing or a monument of film genius.  While the acting was better then many indie films, it still left something to be desired. In particular, the casting of Miriam Shor to play the male Yitzhak was distracting, though the he/she situation was understandably present for more range in the singing.  The whole film had the feel of a broadway musical (for good reason) so if you like theatre translated onto the screen, you may want to check it out.  Furthermore, and maybe I'm one of the few, I thought the story itself was a little lacking in depth...an average (yet wildly colorful and unique) story hidden behind edgy musical numbers (most of which I liked, though I only REALLY enjoyed one of them), exotic costumes, and silliness (which I sadly could never remove from my mind).  So all in all, it was a well-done film and one that if you get a chance, you should watch...but nonetheless, there are many movies out there that are indeed much better.

reviews.review_title: I just want to know when we'll see more..
reviews.content: A wonderful story of love and the horrors of mistaking the wrong person for your soulmate. I've watched this movie over and over again, getting something new out of it every time. The music is great all by itself, but the way it tells Hedwig's story is inspired. The folks who made this movie need to share more of their talents with us. And if any of them read this... thank you.

reviews.review_title: Reminiscent of Rocky Horror, only good.
reviews.content: I have recently heard that this movie is playing midnight shows the way Rocky Horror did, and has been called the new Rocky Horror. Now I have seen Rocky Horror more than I can count, and yes it is a great theater experience, but there is a big difference between these movies: Hedwig is fabulous! They both have great music, but Hedwig is a great story too!(I don't care what anyone says, Rocky Horror without an audience is crap). Now I have only seen Hedwig in the comfort of my tiny basement, and loved it, I hope i get a chance to see it in a theater and share the experience with others-Signed a Heterosexual mother of two.

I LOVED THIS MOVIE!!!!!  I rented the DVD and not only did I watch it 3 times but I watched every bit of bonus material on the disc,(highly recommended) including the entire movie over again with the director's commentary.  I am still singing the songs and I can't wait to get my own copy of both the DVD and the CD. I can't explain it, this movie has the ability to have a profound effect on one's life. I find it very inspiring for some reason. I know this sounds ridiculous. On some level, I found myself identifing with Hedwig and even loved her/him.  By the time you get to the end of the film, you've gone along this incredible journey with Hedwig and somehow grown along with her/him.  The last song, Midnight Radio, is fabulous! I would put it up there with The Who's See Me Feel Me/ Listening to You at the end of Tommy, in terms of inspiration. All of the songs are extremely memorable.  The Origin of Love, is a great song and the animation that goes along with it really enhances it.  I loved everything about this movie, especially JCM!  His Hedwig was positively HOT! Dare I say as hot as Tim Curry's Frank? The story is deeply moving and leaves you thinking on many different levels. I only wish I had seen the play. I give this movie 10/10.  I loved it for so many reasons. I can't wait to see it again.

My husband and I borrowed this movie after stumbling upon the title here on IMDb. We were prepared to moan and groan our way through it, or simply turn it off and read the paper in bed. I must say, we were both hooked from the menu. Half way through we were still looking at each other, amazed that it hadn't yet devolved into some truly cheesy schlock that makes you embarrassed for the actors. And it never did.There isn't anything not to like about this movie, even the music was good. There were some truly memorable scenes and quotes. It was as much fun as Spinal Tap.

Hedwig and the Angry Inch is one of those surprise movies and real pleaser. I was knocked out by the performance of John Cameron Mitchell as Hedwig. The dialogue is hilarious, the songs are catchy and fun and the ending is profound.  Go see it and get the soundtrack.

I just saw this movie on TV and I am a BIG fan of cult movies...this one was fabulous! It gave me chills...the movie made you feel the way Hedwig was feeling...really really fabulous. Also very interesting cast...weird...Fascinating would be the term.The music in this movie was also wonderful. From wild and Punk...to sensitive, needy and loving... 2 Thumbs up. Go and see. I need the soundtrack. I gave this movie a fat well deserved 10! A must-see for cult movie lovers! Shivers down my spine...so much passion...and so much loneliness...Black humor enough. It's a miracle that I never heard about this movie before, nor saw any advertising. Shame.

It's not "Rocky Horror"...it's more than that.  It's about finding yourself after being torn apart.  Hedwig is funny, tragic, glamorous and ugly.  It's a deep movie and yet anyone can relate to it.  Try Hedwig once and if you like a movie with a plot, and great music you'll enjoy it!!

This film introduced me to a new genre of film altogether. After reading the back of the video case I was slightly embarrassed by the outline of the movie. After watching I was captured by the pure brilliance of the songs and the absolutely brilliant ending.The main character is Hedwig, a German transsexual singer. A weird main character perhaps but with such an immense character it will be impossible to turn away. Parts of the story are told through song and these songs are extremely emotive.This has to be my favourite "cult classic" of all time, it's unique in every way and it's one of those films which just has to be watched! 10 out of 10, magnificent!

reviews.review_title: Great movie, great music, great message.
reviews.content: Perhaps one of the best movies I've seen this year.  The music is simply fantastic and adds the extra exposition in the beginning without giving too much information.  Hedwig remains an enigma throughout the film, but we are able to watch the soulful journey to acceptance that the characters undertake.  Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: It's a carwash, ladies and gentlemen!
reviews.content: Without a doubt this is my favorite movie, with Citizen Kane and the Godfather far far behind in second and third.  It is a sincere, honest, heart-breaking and hilarious masterpiece that should be a requirement for anyone who has ever felt lonely or in need of acceptance or--well, anyone who has ever felt human.  I've tried to convince people to see it but they're always put off by the "transsexual rock and roller in a trailer park" idea...if this is you, SEE IT ANYWAYS.  Those are only the details--the themes are universal.And as for the music...oh my god, the music!  I first heard of this movie in June of 2001, two months before it was released here, so I had plenty of time to become obsessed with just the music.  (Confession: I haven't changed the hedwig soundtrack cd out of my cd player since June and don't plan to any time soon.)  Watching the movie with the fabulous outfits, beautiful John Cameron Mitchell (I wish I looked that good in a dress!), deep emotions, hilarious one-liners AND the wonderful music made it a completely draining but fulfilling experience in the best way possible.  If I ever feel down, I just watch JCM and lovely Stephen Trask in the "wig in a box" scene--it can cheer me out of any muck."Know in your soul, like your blood knows the way from your heart to your brain, know that you're whole!"  --Midnight Radio (Stephen Trask)(The DVD is also fabulous--great documentary on the origin of Hedwig, directors comments, etc)10 stars out of 5.

reviews.review_title: There aren't words to describe how great this movie is
reviews.content: If there was a word more descriptive than "great", or a concept that would tell you more than "fantastic" this would be the time to use it.  I watch this film at least once a week I'm so in love with Hedwig.  While I shouldn't feel the need to respond to the what, 3 bad reviews of this film, there is this part of me blown away that someone could not like it!To the person who said that none of the characters were "believable" - you need to watch the film again and realize they aren't supposed to be "real" people per se.  Suspend disbelief!!That said, watch this movie and just enjoy yourself.  It's too much fun and too dazzling to handicap it with ideas of the real world.  It's non stop funny, intelligent, incredibly well crafted and inspiring just because it provides you with an opportunity to see what happens when great minds push their own creativity and genius.Mensa festival...how much funnier can you get!?!?!

Hedwig and the Angry Inch is a film so well written/acted and with so much style and class that even those of you out there who do not normally like musicals and/or dislike gay cinema can enjoy it along with the rest of us. Fantastic catchy songs are perfectly mixed into an involving and well paced storyline. John Cameron Mitchell's directing talent can clearly be seen by looking at the performance of newcomer Michael Pitt in this wonderful film versus his performance in the unbelievably lame Bully. I think it's best not to discuss the story line at all. The songs tell the story and I'm not going to give any of them away. Mitchell should have been nominated (although I have no respect for the Academy Awards farce that takes place each year) for an award for best screenplay and best director. "The Origin of Love" should also have been nominated for best original song. The idiots at the Academy are too busy slapping themselves on the back for giving actors "make up awards" for past work (defeating the whole purpose) to acknowledge this masterpiece of cinema. See it (if you can find it) at all costs!

reviews.content:
Very good film, especially the soundtrack. My favorite part of the film. The feeling John Cameron Mitchell puts into "Angry Inch" was amazing. I really do love this movie. I'm making all my friends see it.
***~~~***SPOILERS***~~~***Well, actually, my favorite part of the movie is the fact that Yitzhak's character was played by a woman, Miriam Shor(*That's* why he looked so good as a woman at the end, and why he sang in a high, falsetto-like voice) and as we all know, Hedwig Robinson (Not Hedwig Schmitt his mother) was played by John Cameron Mitchell. I think I shall go watch this film again. Bye!

reviews.review_title: This movie leaves you in a wake of rainbow carnage!
reviews.content: When I first saw the preview for this film, I knew I needed to see it. Rock star drama, original songs by Stephen Trask, and a most unconventional love plot. What I didn't know was what a truly sincere story I was in for. Hedwig's story is one to which we all can relate, male or female, gay or hetero. While the inner-feelings of the story may be hidden under layers of glitter makeup and punk rock clothing, Hedwig is a character who represents finding yourself and then falling in love with that person. We all have our idiosyncrasies and hang-ups, some of which make us think we are unlovable, or perhaps not worthy of love. Hedwig's quest to find his/her other half takes the audience on a triumphant journey through time and place, searching desperately to find that which makes Hedwig whole. The animation bits that accompany bits of plot and song are amazing, very raw and real. They evoke images of youth and playfulness that today's technology could not dream of aspiring to. The song "Origin of Love" perhaps sums up the sentiment of the film. When I first saw the film, I almost cried with joy when the "music video" unfolded on the screen before me as one of my very favorite Greek texts. Taken from Aristophanes' Theory on the Origin of Love from Plato's Symposium, the song describes how love was born on the planet. At the dawn of human existence, there were three sexes, each consisting of two people attached on their backsides. Think Siamese twins, but with faces on each side rather than side by side. The Children of the Sun were two men, the Children of the Earth were two women, and the Children of the Earth were one of each. The Gods became threatened by the peaceful and powerful existence that these beings enjoyed, so when they tried to scale Mount Olympus (think of them rolling around like cart wheeling bowling balls), the Gods smite them and take away the source of their power, their duality. They are split down the middle, separating the halves, thus creating this feeling of longing we have for one another. Ever since, people sometimes spend a lifetime looking for their other half. While the song is only a small portion of the film, one an only imagine that John Cameron Mitchell used it as the centerpiece to his masterpiece, breathing new, yet ancient, life into his charismatic, and hilarious, character, Hedwig. The end result is comedic tragedy, sweet, innocent love wrapped in an androgynous body. Proving that it's what's inside that counts and f*ck the world if they don't love you, Hedwig and the Angry Inch is the 21st century's first hard-hitting musical that brings it all the way home.

First, I liked the use of flashback; cartoon; & the hyper-real, as in the inclusion of babies, the tour meetings, the pseudo documentary scenes. It might be criticism that the plot premise is established in the first 15 mins, and where do you go from there? But, 'Story of Love' cements the plot as a quest for the other 1/2, and that held my interest thereafter. I liked the knowing humour, like: - You Kant always get what you want, wrt to German philosophy I liked the way, in the scenes depicting the first expressions of overt homoeroticicsm {not sure if this is the term}, sarcastic use was made of homoerotic symbolism, so obvious, so symbolic, so obvious it was laughable, it made fun of those who want to find deep symbolism in movies like this (the gummi bears scene). I liked the Country music parody scene, though I wondered about suspension of disbelief when the music carried on while the musicians were fighting?! To those who have compared this movie to 'Rocky Horror', I would say forget it, that movie had transsexualism, but this movie is far more about it I thought it slowed a bit in the middle, but on the whole was pretty good. A lesson to all those securely heterosexual people who think they are common, but forget there are rarer birds; and an inspiration to all those rarities.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films ever
reviews.content: The main character gets all of life's junk thrown at her, and she never whines about it. That doesn't sound to articulate, but it feels as though most modern "feelings" movies have the main characters whine a whole lot which make them less likable. Nobody likes a cry-baby, and Hedwig is definitely not one. In addition to that, the music is incredible, the acting is great, and the dialogue creates enough interest and a good enough pace to propel the movie through over 10 years without leaving the audience feeling that anything important was left out. A good movie to watch but you have to be in the mood for something weird and with the right crowd (definitely not appropriate for children).

This film far out-lived my expectations. It's much more than just a musical about a drag queen.  There are elements of deep, soul-bearing psychology, self-examination, judgement,perception,mythology,love...all against an element of history which metaphorically represents the struggle of Hedwig. The music ROCKS too. A hero for anyone thats willing to face the music, so to speak, Hedwig is the personification of what many fear: a soul unwilling to stop thriving.Hedwig ROCKS!

I despise musicals.  I hate the Rocky Horror Picture Show, Tommy bores me, Heavy Metal even fails to capture my attention.  Dancer in the Dark was the first modern musical that captivated me, but that had a non-musical plot. Hedwig and the Angry Inch is a full blown rock opera adapted from a NYC play for the screen, the movie is a mixture of fantastic animation, catchy music, bordering-on-genius lyrics, and a diverse cast that maintains your attention without apparent effort.  The story of a german asexual transvestite and his cast of unique bandmates, their lives, their music (and the famous rock star that stole it to become famous), and their personal growth in coming to terms with their personal desires.  Hedwig has a voice in both speaking and singing that is mesmerizing.  The movie is very colorful, unique, fresh and all around amazing.  My only dislikes about this film were at some points, it was a little too artsy -- leaving the audience to understand what it meant rather than helping them to understand (the main reason I don't like a lot of performance art) which in and of itself is not bad (art is interpretive, I know) but some of these items seemed essential to following the plot.  You don't get lost, but you aren't quite at the finish line either.  This, however, does not make the movie unwatchable by any means. It just means you have to sit through this gem of a movie a few more times to understand, and I will do so happily.

reviews.review_title: The best candidate ever for a gay crossover hit.
reviews.content: John Cameron Mitchell is a two-fisted head-butting ball busting force of nature. The music is haunting visceral and unforgettable. At least three songs belong at the top of the charts. This film delivers the goods. The best candidate ever for a gay crossover hit.I've never enjoyed drag shows, affected limp wristed gay talk, or any part of the whole gay milieu. And I didn't expect to enjoy this film. But half way through found my self cheering as the lead character angrily sang about his botched sex change operation to an angry and violent crowd. The garish tackiness was transcended by the sublime courage of a person determined to express himself herself whatever.This film is a triumph.

reviews.review_title: A bizarre but amazing love story
reviews.content: The first time I watched Hedwig, I cried. The second time (same day) we tried to write down the beautiful words for each song. This movie touched me deeply and at my age, 33, is in my top 5. I bought the DVD and CD and lend them out to all because i want the Hedwig attitude out there. Will sound really silly, but last week, having not seen it for 2 months cos i have lent it out, i had a dream that a graphic designer friend made me Hedwig hair! Such beautiful story, such amazing music...Once you get past the amazing story you realise it is the most amazing love song,.... just not the kind that Hollywood pumps out. I recommend you show this to anyone who isn't prejudiced, and even some who are. Everyone can appreciate the sentiment of true love gone astray...

The film Hedwig and the Angry Inch is an astonishingly complex work.  The soundtrack is fabulous, the filmography is very well done, and the story is intriguing.  It's very much worth the money to see in the theater with surround sound.  I was very impressed by John Cameron Mitchell's performance in the movie, he plays his part to a T.  I'd certainly expect to see this film nominated for some Oscars.

reviews.review_title: The most beautiful movie ever, besides Cabaret
reviews.content: I watched this for the first time today. I was totally blown away. I love when Hedwig/Hansel finally finds the courage to walk through the alley alone, naked in all his glory, in the dark, in the rain, into "mankind" and the world, and finally says, hey, this is me, love me! I love me! I cried and laughed through the whole movie. Hedwig, I love you! You are special. You have more balls than anyone I know!!!!!!!!!!! :)) I love to watch people in their lives, and how they handle them. Hedwig/Hansel was so trusting and loving and only wanted to be accepted and loved. Don't we all want that? He made the most of him/herself. He was who he was. Who are we to judge? God does not make trash. He made us all different for a reason. So we could all love and cherish each other. I loved it when he and Tommy finally got drunk in the limo and Tommy sort-of, half-assed actually acknowledged Hedwig and the love he had in his beautiful heart and the sacrifices he made. Tommy was an asshole and he knew it, and he knew how much he hurt Hedwig. The guilt he felt must have been overwhelming.

This movie was a superb example of what the mainstream media is scared of. It features a cross-dressing glam rock princess who has never gotten over her past, especially her latest scar, the ex-boyfriend who stole her music. I saw it on IFC at around 11 and was immediately hooked even though I had only turned on the television to keep me company while doing the dishes. After the first 5 minutes, I rushed through the last dishes to sit down and better hear the dialogue. This film was very well scripted, not to mention the catchy and equally heart wrenching lyrics. As soon as the credits rolled around, I wrote down the information where I could find the soundtrack. This film was rather and might I say with a title like Hedwig and the Angry Inch, surprisingly good. I completely recommend it to anyone looking for a good movie, excellent script, awesome actors, strange premise and a soundtrack that won't make you cringe.

This wonderful movie has become my all-time favourite. Not that you need to know this, but when I rented it a while ago and I sat down to watch it, I ended up spending over six hours straight just watching everything on the DVD (the movie four times, once with the commentary on). The first time I watched it I had a very open mind and I just went into it not expecting anything. I just kind of sat there watching and watching it, with this amused look on my face, bursting out laughing a only couple of times. After I saw the whole thing for the first time, I actually didn't find it brilliant or genius, I only thought it weird, but good. However, something from the movie pulled me in and I kept watching it over and over again. I think I watched it six or seven times once I'd returned the seven-day rental.Anyway, it has become sacred in my mind. I personally really connected to the movie on an emotional level because of the beautiful story of this lost creature, just looking to be complete and to feel absolutely comfortable in her own skin. And on top of that, you have great, just amazingly great tunes, and you have a very large element of humour in it as well. It has a bit of an odd sense of humour, though, but I personally am into that kind of thing. I think it's a very well-rounded movie, as it has so many moods and ups and downs. That is to say, it doesn't snap from extreme to extreme, it flows very well.The movie is also very colourful and pleasing to the eye to watch. The costumes are wonderful, extravagant outfits, the make-up and hair is always great. The shifting of colour tints (or whatever you call it...saturation, etc.) in the film itself as Hedwig tells the story through flashbacks, and as the story tells itself in the 'present', also really helps bring the story to life on screen.All in all, a really, really awesome movie.

I must admit, when I first started to hear buzz about Hedwig, I had no desire to see it. O how wrong can one person be. This movie has taught me so much, especialy about friendships. I can not say enough good things about this movie, It is a must see for everyone. John C. Mitchell has taken his place along side the few others on my short list of heros. If you have a friend who has been your mentor in any way, you have to see this movie; it will make you realize how lucky you are to have that person.

Don't you believe that Hedwig did the most amazingly brilliant thing at the end of the show? To come out and show the world, and say "This is me world, this is what you're gonna get"; and to pass on the wig to someone else who really needed the opportunity to show what he was really feeling. Yitzhak just wanted to be glamorous, and finally got to be who he really felt at the end. John Cameron Mitchell did such a fantastic job portraying Hedwig, and her entire range of emotions were beyond brilliant. Stephan Trask, the songs he wrote couldn't have been better. His ability to write songs that don't tear the film down, they only uplifted it. I admire and respect John Cameron Mitchell for every risk he took. Hedwig Robinson, you are amazing. A thousand praises. Cheers

I was very skeptical of seeing this movie, but I decided to give it a fair chance.  I'm very glad that I did, as I've realized that this movie is the definitive rock musical.  The music is as angry, emotional, and telling as the plot is, and it is very easy to become attached to all of the characters in Hedwig for this reason.  Most musicals spend more time entertaining, and not enough time developing the characters, but Hedwig is an exception.  The characters are all three dimensional, and you can't help but feel incredibly sympathetic towards them.  Hedwig can be viewed as eye candy due to the vibrant, colorful imagery and energetic performances, but it also maintains a deep, heart-warming plot that feels more realistic than I could have ever imagined.  A word of caution to the weak-stomached and/or close-minded, though.  I give it a perfect 10.

This film is about becoming "Whole". Hedwig went through so many up's and down's in her life and still was standing after all, yet she was seaching for her "Other half" in ,what she thought, was another person out there. In the end she found both her male and female sides and her own unique self and became "Whole" within herself. Through all the music and clutter of this film, this is what it all boils down to..self-acceptance. Very cool.

I loved this movie.  The music is wonderful!! I was blasting the vcr and dancing.  I'm still signing about makeup and 8 tracks.  I got many makeup ideas!  I just really enjoyed it.  It was a feel good movie. Do yourself a favor and rent this one!!

reviews.review_title: It will make you want to buy the soundtrack
reviews.content: I saw the movie in theatres when it first came out as a recommendation from a freind. The music makes the movie really happen. A wonderful story just brought to life. I just watched the DVD with the same friend tonight and I was once again amazed by the film, so amazed that I went and got the soundtrack to it... well worth it. I don't want to call this a musical but the movie is a definate "must-see".

reviews.review_title: Not just another glam-rock film (wouldn´t that be enough, anyway?)
reviews.content: Wonderful... For all those who thought all about glam rock had already been said in "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" and "Velvet Goldmine", here is a film to prove you wrong. And it is also not just another musical film, or even a musical poured into a film. It´s beautifully displayed (cinematography, art direction...), wonderfully acted, and above it all... it screams out that glam is not dead, and it can still be painted in a sophisticated and outrageous way. It is always a relief to see that the 80´s could not kill it after all (note: throughout the film, David Bowie still proves he has always been a rock ´n roll messiah).

Saw this movie sometime ago and immediately bought both the soundtrack (all the better to play in the car) as well as the DVD. Nether have left their respective player components since.As has been described ad nauseum here - this is the story of a girly slip of a boy's journey from communist eastern block Berlin to Kansas City and notoriety as he enters into a law suit for the shared credits and reciepts to the songs that are generating fame and fortune for the countries most famous rock and roll icon who refuses to aknowledge him.We start the movie with Hedwig bursting angrily onto stage delivering the raw, powerful song "Enemies and adversaries" Every torch singer joke is pulled thrown at the audience and its easy at this point to write Hedwig off as simply another painted man on stage, with the novel twist that this one can actually sing his own songs .. but very little more depth is presented - much as one might write off any transexual or stripper on stage.But behind the heavy make up brash lyrics and pat one liners the movie begins to slowly flesh out the man behind the make-up. We are shown snippets of Hedwigs journey to the States from his life in the Eastern block, his childhood, his mother . I liked this technique - First we are presented the finished product - a man in makeup screaming out anger on a tired stage - not the kinda person too many of the audience would relate to. As soon as your ready to write all this off we are shown Hedwig as a boy - Hansel - in Eastern block Berlin - we are shown snippits of his life and allowed to develop the character into a real person - we are then let into the real motive behind the man in an amazing song "The origin of love" .From this point in the movie onwards the story is told both in Songs and snippets flashing back to the past as well as current day - metaphor is used heavily but not confusingly - every image presented works to provide a richer context for the reason behind why Hedwig is the way he is. We end up with a portrayal of a person most people wouldn't have a hard time recognising in themselves - even if the exterior presentation is packaged somewhat differently.This is one of my favorite movies of all time - a classic that I predict will gain in popularity as time marches on. 9/10.

The "I may be down, but screw you I'm not out!" spirit of punk resounds throughout the plot accompanied by one of the best original soundtracks I've ever heard.When you hear the song "Angry Inch" with it's hard riffs, angry vocals and uncomfortably In-Your-Face subject matter, you'll dare anyone to tell you punk is dead. It may not be heard every day, but the spirit of punk lives in Hedwig!I would have given this film a 9.5, had IMDb allowed it, as my reason for not giving it a ten is a minor annoyance with the soundtrack. Since this was originally adapted from a stage production, the actors could have taken the cheap way out and simply moved their lips to the songs from the original production. This didn't happen here. The actors in the movie re-recorded their vocals for this movie, even though most of the actors are the same ones from the stage production. This gives the soundtrack an amazing live feel throughout the movie. However, one of the actors from the stage production, a woman, was not in the movie. However, this is so rarely noticeable that I did not see it until I was looking for it, so it's really not a big deal.

Hedwig and the Angry Inch is so much more than just the movie at hand. The movie follows the group as they tour the U.S. in the shadow of a rock superstar called Tommy Gnosis (Michael Pitt, playing the would-be Marilyn Manson as rightly slippery, fraudulent, and pathetic) who is currently burning up the charts with Hedwig's songs, credited solely to him.  

John Cameron Mitchell and company transcended a hill that, at the time, very few even realized was a hill at all.  The hill might've been a strange and unidentifiable mound of flesh only one inch high, but cross it we must, if empathy is to triumph over hatred, selfishness and division.  A botched sex change makes for strange terrain but work with it (in a very broader sense) we must.  We move may only move six inches forward and five inches back, but in eighteen years, the angry inch gained is progress.  For us, it's an origin of love, if not the origin of love.

Reviewed 5.30.19  John. Cameron. Mitchell.  He absolutely owns this film.  If you've ever suspected the Academy Awards are a sham, here's your evidence.  He wasn't even nominated (although the generally clueless Golden Globes did, go figure).  It's one part Spinal Tap, one part Sex Pistols, and all things queer and wonderful.  Adapted from the stage, Mitchell reprises his role as Hedwig, a performer with a past to match his flamboyant present.  As both writer, director and star, Mitchell is the creative heart, and boy does he shine.  The loose narrative teeters at times, and fails to stick the landing.  But with a performance like this, I was happy to take every inch.

Gender is, no doubt, a doubtful, complicated thing, utterly self-contradictory---femininity defined by men, who define their masculinity in opposition to what makes a woman---and so difficult to positively affirm while impossible to entirely escape. At best, perhaps, rather than simply repudiate gender tout court, aiming for some impossibly neutral middle ground, a gender equilibrium that still reinforces a basic binary while seeking the stasis of the death drive, one must abandon such dichotomies whatsoever to instead see gender as a fluid spectrum with multiple overlapping identity positions. Such is the case for Hedwig, a character whose radical queerness must have been bracing when she first appeared on stage, whose success and longevity helped spark a transformation in queer acceptance that, twenty years later, makes her problematic aspects all the more glaring, reflecting transphobic myths of child abuse and castration anxiety. Still, the film, for good reason, is iconic, innovative, and subversive, blending cinematic and musical genres just as artfully as Hedwig blends gender.

In all honesty, my favourite musical film is The Rocky Horror Picture Show due to the over the top nature of its flamboyance and the fact that it just broke convention so much. Hedwig and the Angry Inch similarly deals with transgender related subject matter without sucking up to cliches of the musical genre. 
Unlike Rock of Ages, Hedwig and the Angry Inch is an actual rock musical. The songs in the film actually maintain rock spirit without having to force it into commercial territory as a means of achieving that or playing songs which are little more than novelty. Hedwig and the Angry Inch is an interesting musical because it tells its story through music without it being at the expense of dialogue, and yet at the same time it works as an effective character study for the titular character. The main focus of the film is on the titular protagonist as she tells her life story through music and flashbacks, as well as conveying all of her feelings. This never feels melodramatic, it feels touching and also spirited with all the energy of the songs. Frankly, Hedwig and the Angry Inch knows how to succeed as an effective narrative feature and a good musical at the same time, disregarding all the conventions put out by Hollywood cinema and taking a new path which proves successful. The musical and narrative structure of the film may not always be effectively balanced which can throw viewers off due to a sense of inconsistency, but those who are able to sit back and embrace the over the top nature of many elements in Hedwig and the Angry Inch should approve of it. For me, I got thrown off by this quite a bit as well as the fact that I was so interested in the film that I wanted a lot more from it, setting my expectations a bit high. The fact that some of the subject matter is simplified is important because it reminds us that transgender people are everyday people just like you and me, but I also felt like there was much more of a story to be told. The titular character Hedwig was such an intruiging character who has been through so much, and I guess the fact that the film really wanted to explore it all on location made me think that the scale of Hedwig and the Angry Inch would be larger than it actually was. If it were a stage production then it would be easier to embrace, but because it is a film I felt that it did not maintain enough narrative to precisely constitute a cinematic experience as a whole. But still, the general spirit of it all is there and John Cameron Mitchell has the best intentions at heart.
Frankly, Hedwig and the Angry Inch is a groovy film. It may not be perfect, but its stylish glamour combined with its legitimate drama and complicated themes make it an effective medium for viewers to learn about transgender identity and love while sitting back and embracing the wonderful music of it all. It is clearly a very personal piece for John Cameron Mitchell and essentially his Citizen Kane due to the fact that he serves as the writer, director and star of the film. We have him to thank for everything in Hedwig and the Angry Inch, and his passionate spirit is wonderful in how it brings the story to life on screen. The main problem I have with Hedwig and the Angry Inch is that I wanted more, and that the short running time of the film was not enough to fully explore the concept as well as it should have been. But either way, Hedwig and the Angry Inch remains an effectively entertaining feature which stands out as a well crafted film and an effective directorial debut from John Cameron Mitchell.
Also, there is no denying the sense of style in Hedwig and the Angry Inch. With the scenery so accurately conveying a sense of various settings throughout the film but a production design which remains simple, Hedwig and the Angry Inch is a colourful film. The cinematography evokes the feel of a documentary at many times which adds to the dramatic effect of the intended legitimacy in the film while at other times the cinematography is used very atmospherically to create a sense of melancholy to reflect the emotional experiences of the titular protagonist. John Cameron Mitchell finds ways to effectively tie the stylish nature of the film into the narrative as director and writer, and he uses it all to surround himself which hypes of the character he plays. Luckily enough he plays it perfectly.
John Cameron Mitchell is clearly a very complex man because there is nothing simple about a character like Hedwig Robinson. Effectively enough, John Cameron Mitchell manages to play her to the bone in every area with nothing but expertise. John Cameron Mitchell shows off his singing talents in Hedwig and the Angry Inch to really draw audiences in to the entertaining musical numbers, but more importantly he captures the intrigue of viewers with just how dedicated he is to the role. He captures the dramatic spirit of the character by conveying just how difficult it is to exist in a society which rejects the concept of accepting transgender women. He manages to really show just how difficult it is to live with such pressure and such complex psychology. John Cameron Mitchell captures the depth of his role and the spirit which transcends it to make Hedwig Robinson a rock star at the same time, easily going between the two personas without fear or struggles at transitioning. His performance is what really draws viewers in, and he directs himself through the material with incredible finesse which makes it one of the more memorable transgender character to be portrayed on the cinematic screen.

So thanks to John Cameron Mitchell's tenacious leading performance and powerful work as writer and director, Hedwig and the Angry Inch is an entertaining and touching musical film despite its narrative inconsistencies and short running time.
